0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Ascorbic acid deficiency: mild to moderate deficiency, 100 to 250 mg IM/IV/SC or ORALLY once or twice daily
  • Ascorbic acid deficiency: severe, 1 to 2 g IM/IV/SC per day
  • Ascorbic acid deficiency: recommended dietary allowance, men, 90 mg/day; women, 75 mg/day; pregnancy, 85 mg/day; lactation, 120 mg/day
  • Burn (Severe): 200 to 500 mg/day up to 1 to 2 g/day IM/IV/SC or ORALLY until healing or completion of grafting
  • Wound healing: 300 to 500 mg/day IM/IV/SC or ORALLY for a wk to 10 days preoperatively and postoperatively

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Ascorbic acid deficiency: 100 mg 3 times/day IM/IV/SC or ORALLY for 1 wk, then 100 mg daily for several wk until tissue saturation is reached
  • Ascorbic acid deficiency: recommended dietary allowance, age 0 to 6 months, 40 mg/day; 7 to 12 months, 50 mg/day; 1 to 3 y, 15 mg/day; 4 to 8 y, 25 mg/day; 9 to 13 y, 45 mg/day; males 14 to 18 y, 75 mg/day; females 14 to 18 mg/day 65 mg/day
  • Burn (Severe): 200 to 500 mg/day IM/IV/SC or ORALLY until healing or grafting is complete

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Ascorbic acid deficiency
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • AIDS virus infection associated with pregnancy
  • Anemia of chronic renal failure
  • Burn (Severe)
  • Hypertension
  • Iron supplement therapy; Adjunct
  • Multiple organ failure; Prophylaxis
  • Radiographic contrast agent nephropathy; Prophylaxis
  • Wound healing

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: hypersensitivity to any component of the preparation

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• concurrent anticoagulant therapy
  • concurrent sodium-restricted diet
  • diabetes
  • recurrent renal calculi
  • patients undergoing stool occult blood tests
  • some brands of injectable vitamin C contain sulfites (can cause allergic reactions, including anaphylaxis, in susceptible individuals)
  • some brands contain benzyl alcohol (avoid in premature infants)
  • doses of 500 mg/day or more can interfere with urinary glucose tests
  • no exogenous vitamin C should be ingested 48-72 hr before an amine-dependent stool occult blood test
  • high doses during pregnancy can cause scurvy in newborn infant
  • because of pressure build-up in ampules, wrap ampule with covering while opening

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Injection site reaction, Pain and swelling
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea, Large doses
  • Hematologic:Iron overload, Large doses
  • Renal:Nephrolithiasis, Large doses

2.title: Class
2.mono:
• Nutritive Agent
  • Vitamin C (class)
  • Vitamin Combination
  • Vitamin Combination, Adult Formula

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) is a water-soluble vitamin and an antiscorbutic product that is essential for collagen formulation and tissue repair. It plays a significant role in the metabolism of tyrosine, carbohydrates, iron, folic acid conversion to folinic acid, synthesis of lipids and proteins, resistance to infections and cellular respiration. It supports the immune system of the body through its antioxidant property that helps neutralize harmful free radicals in cells.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    pressure may develop within vials during storage; use care when withdrawing and/or relieve pressure by first inserting sterile empty syringe into vial
  • Intramuscular
    utilization of vitamin C is best after IM administration, making IM the preferred route
  • Intravenous
    (infusion) administer in large volume of parenteral solution such as NS to avoid adverse reactions; avoid rapid IV administration
  • Oral
    preferable to take with a meal
  • Subcutaneous
    may be given SUBQ

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• symptomatic improvement
  • urinary pH
  • (intravenous) renal function, hydration status, voiding capacity; during high-dose therapy

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Larger doses of this drug may cause diarrhea or nephrolithiasis.
  • Patient should preferably take the oral formulation with a meal.
  • Advise patient to report changes in smoking habits (begin smoking, cease smoking) while taking this drug, as dosage may need to be adjusted.
